constructs.name: weekend_work_hours
constructs.description: Amount of time spent on work activities during weekend days

constructs.name: unfinished_weekday_tasks
constructs.description: Volume of work tasks not completed during the Monday-Friday work period that carry over

constructs.name: weekday_productivity
constructs.description: Efficiency and output during regular work hours on weekdays

constructs.name: workload_volume
constructs.description: Total amount of work tasks assigned or committed to in a given period

constructs.name: work_stress
constructs.description: Experienced stress, pressure, and anxiety related to work demands

constructs.name: work_rumination
constructs.description: Intrusive, repetitive thoughts about work during non-work time

constructs.name: sleep_quality
constructs.description: Restorative quality of sleep including ease of falling asleep and feeling rested

constructs.name: energy_levels
constructs.description: Physical and mental energy available throughout the day

constructs.name: boundary_enforcement
constructs.description: Active behaviors to separate work from personal time such as turning off notifications or leaving devices at office

constructs.name: weekend_social_commitments
constructs.description: Planned activities with family, friends, or community on weekends

constructs.name: weekend_recovery_activities
constructs.description: Engagement in hobbies, exercise, relaxation, and restorative non-work activities on weekends

constructs.name: planning_quality
constructs.description: How well work tasks are prioritized, scheduled, and organized during the week

constructs.name: physical_activity
constructs.description: Amount of physical exercise and movement during the day

constructs.name: work_guilt
constructs.description: Feelings of guilt or shame about not working or taking personal time

constructs.name: deadline_pressure
constructs.description: Proximity to and urgency of externally-imposed work deadlines

constructs.name: manager_weekend_communication
constructs.description: Whether managers or colleagues send work communications on weekends

constructs.name: job_role_demands
constructs.description: Structural demands of the job role including on-call requirements and client-facing responsibilities

constructs.name: organizational_culture
constructs.description: Workplace norms regarding work hours, availability expectations, and work-life balance values

constructs.name: workaholism_tendency
constructs.description: Trait-level tendency toward compulsive overworking and difficulty disengaging from work

constructs.name: boundary_setting_self_efficacy
constructs.description: Confidence in one's ability to successfully set and maintain work-life boundaries

constructs.name: social_support_availability
constructs.description: Availability of supportive relationships with family, friends, or partners

edges.description: Tasks not completed during the week create pressure to work on weekends to catch up
High work stress creates anxiety that drives compulsive checking and working on weekends
Intrusive work thoughts during weekends make it harder to resist the urge to work
Active boundary behaviors like turning off notifications reduce weekend work
Feeling guilty about not working drives compensatory weekend work behavior
Scheduled activities with others create competing demands that prevent weekend work
Engagement in hobbies and recovery activities provides alternatives to defaulting to work
Higher productivity during work hours means more tasks completed before the weekend
More total work assigned means more likely to have incomplete tasks at week end
Good planning and prioritization enables more focused efficient work
Better sleep enables better cognitive function and focus during work
Higher energy levels enable sustained focus and output during work hours
High stress impairs concentration and cognitive function reducing productivity
Good sleep directly determines daily energy levels
Regular physical activity increases sustained energy throughout the day
Physical activity promotes better more restorative sleep
Work stress causes rumination and physiological arousal that impairs sleep
Thinking about work at night disrupts ability to fall and stay asleep
Higher work stress leads to more intrusive thoughts about work during off-hours
Having incomplete tasks creates ongoing stress and pressure
Approaching deadlines increase experienced stress levels
Higher workload volume increases daily stress levels
Believing you can set boundaries enables actual boundary-setting behaviors
High stress makes it harder to maintain boundaries as anxiety pushes toward checking work
A culture expecting constant availability makes boundary enforcement socially costly
Weekend emails and messages from management directly trigger work responses
Imminent deadlines directly increase weekend work to meet them
Some roles structurally have higher baseline workload
Some roles like on-call positions structurally require weekend availability
Workaholic tendencies lead to more persistent thoughts about work
Workaholism makes it psychologically harder to maintain boundaries
Workaholic tendencies amplify guilt about taking time off
Cultures that valorize overwork increase guilt about not working
Weekend work crowds out time available for recovery activities perpetuating the cycle
Weekend recovery helps restore and improve sleep quality for the coming week
Recovery activities help reduce accumulated work stress
Working weekends perpetuates the stress cycle by preventing proper recovery
Having incomplete work creates guilt that persists into weekends
Having energy makes it more likely to engage in physical exercise
High stress reduces motivation and perceived time available for physical activity
Higher energy enables better executive function for planning and organizing work
Social commitments often involve recovery activities like shared meals or recreation
High stress leads to social withdrawal and canceling weekend plans
Guilt about not working leads to accepting additional tasks and commitments
Having supportive relationships increases likelihood of weekend social plans
Social support provides a buffer against work-related stress
Supportive relationships facilitate engagement in restorative weekend activities
